In Music, particularly in Synthesizer music, what you call the 'light signature' would be called the 'envelope' -- at 3:56 you describe an "ASR" (Attack time-Sustain %-Release time) envelope, though there are quite a lot. They're used in synths often to control parameters of a sound, such as it's volume, pitch, or filter cutoff. Using different envelopes can emulate different types of sounds from plucks to whole string sections. Envelopes like these can also control all sorts of things (I have a DIY project where my synthesizer can control the color and brightness of a ring of LEDs) through CV, or "Control Voltage"

Synths are really clever bits of engineering, definitely worth learning about!

For anyone with more modest means, I found some success videoing fireflies by using a wide angle prime lens with an ISO setting of 20,000 and a shutter speed of 1/30 second. My camera has a native ISO range of around 100 to 52,000 ISO. Cameras that push ISO readings outside their native range will likely have an unacceptable amount of noise. Prime lenses typically have fewer elements and less glass. Information is lost at every air-glass interface and lenses aren't perfectly transparent. So I believe those are the reasons I had success with a prime lens and not a zoom despite my using the same aperture setting on both lenses. The video I made is best seen on a good monitor, not a cellphone.

Cool thing about crickets How to Estimate Temperature from Chirps

Anyone outside at night listening to crickets “sing” can put Dolbear's Law to the test with this shortcut method:

Pick out the chirping sound of a single cricket.

Count the number of chirps the cricket makes in 15 seconds. Write down or remember this number.

Add 40 to the number of chirps you counted. This sum gives you a rough estimate of the temperature in Fahrenheit.

(To estimate the temperature in degrees Celcius, count the number of cricket chirps heard in 25 seconds, divide by 3, then add 4.)

Some video tips:
Your shutter speed is twice the frame rate, so always try and shoot at 1/50 (25fps) or 160 (30fps). Anything higher will be a lot more processing which is harder in low light, anything lower will give you trippy motion issues and stuttering.
Try to use a smaller aperture like f11 or f5.6 ish, this will give you a much broader amount of things in focus
And finally, crank that ISO, yeah it adds noise and grain—but cameras these days can really handle that well, and you can tackle noise in post sometimes. When you gotta shoot in the dark it's really the best of bad options.

For the casual photographers/videographers:
You can do this to some success with a high sensitivity digital video camera, BUT you MUST use manual focus and a manually set, wide open aperture. An "F-stop" is a multi parameter variable, but basically a lower F-stop means a more open aperture. You can also manually set the camera's ISO to a higher than normal value which adjusts the imaging sensor to be electronically more sensitive to light. It also helps if you can set the camera to a frame rate of 30 or less FPS. This will decrease shutter speed allowing the sensor to gather more light. This makes an extremely short range of focus (not distance from the camera, but the actual width, radially out from the lens, of usable focus) which is why you need to set these manually or else the camera will constantly be trying to focus. Even with careful settings, this also produces a sort of "tunnel vision" effect where the edges of the image will be blurry. The larger the lens diameter the less this edge blur happens. Also slower shutter speed will cause moving objects to create blurred streaks (or (NOT) inter-dimensional, multi-winged flying beings) .

Hey Destin. What you see with the fireflies is Game theory and Complex Systems. Complex behavioral patterns are generated organically and transferred to a series of agents in something called game networks.

It is the same reason why schools of fish and flocks of birds seem to move as if they had the same brain. Each individual seeks to synchronize with another to their left or right. Each flash of light is followed by one from its neighbor who tries to flash at the same time...

Soon and in an exponential curve the whole forest begins to synchronize. That is precisely the reason why you managed to synchronize the fireflies with your LED's.

In complex systems the systems contain more information than the net sum of the information of the parts.

There are simple, complex and chaotic systems. Both are finely related. Systems fluctuate between those states and this is how patterns like the ones you identified in fireflies are born.

And it doesn't just work in animals, it works in physics, chemistry, biology, economics, and in humans. In fact, I have been working for some time on tracing the laws of thermodynamics and motion to economics through game theory and complex systems.
